p.row: Use implicit differentiation to find the points where the parabola defined by $f = 0 has horizontal and vertical tangent lines.
The parabola has horizontal tangent lines at the point(s) $ans1
The parabola has vertical tangent lines at the point(s) $ans2

solution.row: Differentiating implicitly with respect to x gives $df = 0, or ($fy) \, \frac{dy}{dx} = $mfx, and so \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{$mfx}{$fy}. The tangent line to the parabola is horizontal where \frac{dy}{dx} = 0, i.e., where x - y = $amb. The equation of the parabola can be written in the form $f_revised = 0, and x - y = $amb gives $fb = 4y, or y = $b, and x = $a. Hence, the tangent line to the parabola is horizontal at the point $ans1 and nowhere else.

The tangent line the the parabola is vertical where 0 = \frac{dx}{dy} = \frac{$fy}{$mfx}, i.e., where x - y = $ambm2. Together with the last displayed equation of the parabola, this gives $ft1pb - 4y = 0, or y = $an2b, and x = $an2a. Hence, the tangent line to the parabola is vertical at the point $ans2 and nowhere else
